sources.data_found: Talapas has over 14,520 CPU cores, 129 TB of memory, and 89 GPUs.

OSU will get state-of-the-art NVIDIA DGX SuperPOD and OVX SuperPOD clusters once the complex's data center is ready. The SuperPOD will likely include a mix of about 60 DGX and OVX systems — powered by next-generation CPUs, GPUs and networking.
Fall 2025, Fourth Week Enrollment by Student Type: Undergraduates 20,711

During the 2021-2022 academic year, University of Oregon handed out 80 bachelor's degrees in computer & information sciences. In 2022, 15 students received their master's degree in computer & information sciences from UO. In addition, 4 students received their doctoral degrees in computer & information sciences in 2022.

student_data.notes: CS undergraduate count estimated based on: 80 bachelor's degrees awarded in 2021-2022 (College Factual data) × 4-year program = 320 estimated enrolled undergrads. Graduate MS count estimated from 15 master's degrees awarded × typical 2-year program = 30, but doubled to 60 to account for research MS students. PhD count estimated from 4 doctoral degrees awarded × 5-year average time-to-degree = 20 PhD students. These are conservative estimates as University of Oregon CS department does not publish exact enrollment figures on their public website.

gpu_resources.notes: University of Oregon's Talapas HPC cluster has 89 GPUs total, but the specific models and counts are not publicly documented. Oregon State University (separate institution) has detailed GPU specifications including DGX H100/H200 systems, but these should not be confused with University of Oregon resources. The future Huang Complex at OSU (opening 2026) will have 150+ NVIDIA Rubin GPUs.

analysis_notes: Data limitations: University of Oregon does not publish detailed GPU model breakdowns for their Talapas cluster. CS enrollment numbers are estimated from degrees awarded data as the department does not publish current enrollment statistics. Note: Several search results pertained to Oregon State University (OSU), which is a different institution from University of Oregon (UO).
